Boost Log Library Documentation

Version 1.4

Modifier/ Appender functions

Header to include:
#include <boost/log/functions.hpp>
// for extra functions, which depend on at least one other Boost library
#include <boost/log/extra/some_other_header.hpp>

When you want to modify some logs' behavior, you can add Modifiers and/or Appenders.

The modifier is a function that modifies the original message that was written to the log, while the Appender is a function that is called to output the message to a destination.

Examples of modifiers:

  • prepend the time (in a given format) to the original message
  • append an enter to the message, if not already found
  • prepend the log' name (example, if the log is named "app.charts.dbg", prepend this to the message)

Examples of Appenders:

  • write to console
  • write to a file
  • write to the Output Debug Window (on Windows OS only)

The modifiers and Appenders are any function/ functor (a class with an overloaded operator()) that match these:

void modifier_func(const std::string & log_name, std::string &msg);

void appender_func(  const std::string & log_name, const std::string &msg);

Examples:

// Modifier
void prepend_prefix(const string & log_name, string & msg) {
    msg = '[' + log_name + "] " + msg;
}

// Appender
void write_to_cout(const std::string &, const std::string &msg) { 
    std::cout << msg; 
}

When a message is written to this log, the following things happen:

  • the library inspects whether the message should be written or not (based on the log's level and the message's level). If message should be written, continue; otherwise, ignore the rest
  • all Modifier functions get called
  • all Appender functions get called

To see how to manipulate existing logs/ hierarchies of logs, click here.
